questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mechanically

 

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors show mechanical coupling involving structural interaction between the two.
  • Excitation-contraction coupling in both skeletal and cardiac muscle depends on structural and functional interactions between the voltage-sensing dihydropyridine receptor L-type Ca (2+) channels in the surface/transverse tubular membrane and ryanodine receptor Ca (2+) release channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane.
  • The channels are targeted to either side of a narrow junctional gap that separates the external and internal membrane systems and are arranged so that bi-directional structural and functional coupling can occur between the proteins. There is strong evidence for a physical interaction between the two types of channel protein in skeletal muscle.
  • It is thought to occur by a "mechanical coupling" mechanism involving protein-protein interactions that lead to activation of the sarcoplasmic reticulum ryanodine receptor by the voltage-sensing transverse (1-) tubule dihydropyridine receptor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemically: This would imply that the interaction is mediated by a chemical messenger, which is not the case for DHPR and RyR coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option B. Electrically: Electrical coupling would imply that the interaction is mediated by an electric signal directly, which is not the mechanism in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. Chemically and then electrically: This combination is incorrect as the coupling is purely mechanical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically, meaning their interaction and functional coupling rely on direct physical contacts between these protein structures to initiate muscle contraction.

choices.text: It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight
Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy
Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia

 

The false statement regarding acitretin is that it is contra-indicated in persons with hyperlipidemia.

 

Although, acitretin can result in increase in serum LDL-cholesterol and triglycerides and decrease in HDL-cholesterol, this adverse effect is more likely in patients with disturbances of lipid metabolism, diabetes mellitus, obesity, increased alcohol intake, or a familial history of these conditions. Therefore, serum lipids must be more closely monitored in high-risk patients and during long-term treatment. Dietary modifications, reduction in dose, or drug therapy should be employed to control significant elevations of triglycerides. If, despite these measures, hypertriglyceridemia and low HDL levels persist, the discontinuation of acitretin should be considered. So, acitretin is not contra-indicated in these patients, but should be used cautiously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acitretin can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight, and patients should be advised to use sun protection and avoid excessive sun exposure during therapy.

 

Option C. Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy: Female patients of childbearing age should avoid getting pregnant after therapy because acitretin is teratogenic and can cause fetal malformations. Effective contraception should be used during treatment and for at least 3 years after therapy.

 

Option D. Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours, which means it can take several weeks for the drug to be eliminated from the body after discontinuing therapy. This long half-life also means that accumulation of the drug can occur with repeated dosing, increasing the risk of toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acitretin is not contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia, although lipid levels should be monitored during therapy. The drug increases sensitivity to sunlight, requires women to avoid pregnancy for 3 years after therapy due to its teratogenicity, and has a long half-life of about 50 hours.

questions.text: Bile Esculin Agar is used for the identification of: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Enterococcus faecalis

 

Explanation:

 

Bile Esculin Agar is specifically used to differentiate between Enterococcus (group D) from other streptococci. This medium helps detect two important characteristics: the ability to grow in the presence of 40% bile and the ability to hydrolyze esculin to esculetin and glucose. When Enterococcus faecalis grows on this medium, the esculetin combines with ferric ions to produce a black complex (phenolic iron complex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes - This is a Group A Streptococcus that doesn't grow well in the presence of bile and doesn't hydrolyze esculin. It's typically identified using other methods such as beta-hemolysis on blood agar and sensitivity to bacitracin.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae - Pneumococci are identified using other methods, particularly optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests. They don't typically grow on bile-containing media.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus - This is actually another name for Streptococcus pneumoniae (the same organism as in option C), so this is incorrect for the same reasons as option C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bile Esculin Agar exploits the unique ability of Group D streptococci (Enterococci) to grow in the presence of bile and hydrolyze esculin, producing a distinctive black color that serves as a valuable diagnostic feature.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with central line insertion performed below the bone indicated by the arrow in the given X-ray image? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

 

Explanation:

 

The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.

 

  • Complications of central vein catheterization are - 
    • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
    • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
    • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
    • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
    • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
    • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
    • Infections

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Thrombophlebitis: Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.

 

Option C. Empyema: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.

 

Option D. Chylothorax: Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.

questions.text: Which phenomenon is regulated by the asymmetrical distribution due to the Gibbs-Donnan effect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Chloride Shift

 

Explanation:

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the distribution of diffusible ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion cannot diffuse through the membrane. The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium establishes that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This principle directly governs the chloride shift, where chloride ions move across red blood cell membranes to maintain electrical neutrality.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Bohr Effect: This refers to hemoglobin's decreased affinity for oxygen when carbon dioxide increases or pH decreases, not regulated by Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.
  • Option C. Haldane Effect: This describes how oxygenation of blood decreases its ability to carry carbon dioxide, not regulated by Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.
  • Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as chloride shift is regulated by Gibbs-Donnan effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect is fundamental to understanding ion distribution across semipermeable membranes, particularly explaining the chloride shift where chloride ions move into red blood cells as bicarbonate moves out.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Optic tract

 

The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

 

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is a type of light reflex. The blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction on illumination, while the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction.

 

It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumors of the optic thalamus.

 

Homonymous hemianopia HH is characteristically seen in optic tract pathway

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve: Incorrect. A lesion in the optic nerve typically results in a loss of vision in the eye served by the affected nerve but does not produce hemianopic pupillary responses. Instead, it might lead to a direct pupillary defect (also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or Marcus Gunn pupil).

 

Option C. Optic radiation: Incorrect. Lesions in the optic radiation cause visual field deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia) but do not affect the pupillary light reflex because the optic radiations carry visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex and are not involved in the reflex arc of the pupil light reflex.

 

Option D. Optic chiasma: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically cause bitemporal hemianopia due to the crossing of nasal retinal fibers at this location. This type of lesion affects the visual fields of both eyes but does not specifically result in a hemianopic pupillary response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lesion site for Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is the optic tract, which when damaged, leads to a characteristic pupillary response where the pupil does not react to light shown on the side of the retina corresponding to the damaged tract. This finding is indicative of a post-chiasmal visual pathway issue and is useful for localizing neurological damage in clinical assessments.

choices.text: Abnormal Expression of MHC Class II Molecule

questions.text: Epstein-Barr virus induces autoimmunity through which of the following mechanisms? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Polyclonal B Cell Activation

 

Explanation:


Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is specifically known to induce autoimmunity through polyclonal B cell activation. This mechanism involves direct stimulation of multiple B cell clones without antigen specificity, leading to excessive antibody production including autoantibodies. EBV can bypass the normal antigen-specific activation pathway, stimulating many B cell clones simultaneously and resulting in hypergammaglobulinemia with potential self-reactive antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molecular Mimicry - This mechanism involves microorganisms sharing antigenic determinants with self-antigens, causing cross-reactive immune responses. While this is a legitimate mechanism of autoimmunity (examples include Shigella flexneri and HLA B27), it's not the primary mechanism by which EBV induces autoimmunity.

 

Option B. Release of Sequestered Antigen - This occurs when normally hidden self-antigens (like spermatozoa or ocular antigens) are released following tissue injury, triggering an immune response. EBV does not primarily operate through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Abnormal Expression of MHC Class II Molecule - While alterations in MHC expression can contribute to autoimmunity, this is not the characteristic mechanism by which EBV induces autoimmune responses.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBV contributes to autoimmunity primarily through polyclonal B cell activation, which results in excessive production of antibodies, including potentially self-reactive ones, independent of specific antigenic stimulation.

questions.text: The ureteric bud arises from which of the following embryological structures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mesonephric duct

 

The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric (or Wolffian) duct. The mesonephric duct is one of the primary structures in the early embryonic development of the urinary and reproductive systems. The ureteric bud's growth is stimulated by signals from the adjacent metanephrogenic blastema. The ureteric bud undergoes repeated branching to form the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and the collecting tubules of the kidneys.

 

  • The intermediate mesoderm is a specific type of mesoderm that is located between the paraxial mesoderm and lateral plate.
  • During development, it plays a crucial role in the formation of both the urogenital system and the reproductive system. It divides into two structures known as the genital ridge and nephrogenic cord.
  • The nephrogenic cord goes on to form three distinct structures - the pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros. From the mesonephros, the ureteric bud develops and eventually fuses with the mesonephric duct.
  • The metanephros then proliferates around the ureteric bud, forming what is called the metanephric blastema. This ultimately gives rise to the definitive kidneys.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metanephros: The metanephros is the embryological structure that develops into the permanent kidney in humans. The metanephrogenic blastema (or metanephrogenic mesenchyme) is the tissue that surrounds the tip of the ureteric bud and interacts with it. Signals from the ureteric bud stimulate the metanephrogenic blastema to differentiate into the nephron components of the kidney (like the glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, etc.). The metanephros is not the origin of the ureteric bud but rather interacts with it.

 

Option C. Pronephros: The pronephros is the most primitive of the three embryonic kidneys. It appears early in embryonic development but quickly degenerates and is non-functional in mammals. Its duct, the pronephric duct, eventually becomes the mesonephric duct when the mesonephros starts to develop. The pronephros itself does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Option D. Genital sinus: The genital sinus is involved in the development of the lower parts of the reproductive system and parts of the urinary system. In females, it contributes to parts of the vagina, and in males, it contributes to parts of the urethra. It does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

A. Dorsal views of the bladder showing the relation of the ureters and mesonephric ducts during development. Initially the ureters are formed by an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct

 

B-D. with time they assume a separate entrance into the urinary bladder

 

C and D. Note the trigone of the bladder formed by incorporation of the mesonephric ducts

questions.text: Which of the following is most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation

 

  • Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.
  • Aldosterone, secreted by the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex, is an important regulator of sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the renal tubules.
  • The primary site of aldosterone action is on the principal cells of the cortical collecting tubule.
  • Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption while at the same time increasing potassium secretion is by stimulating the sodium-potassium ATPase pump on the basolateral side of the cortical collecting tubule membrane.
  • Aldosterone also increases the sodium permeability of the luminal side of the membrane.
  • Minimal levels of aldosterone not affect sodium balance but greatly impairs the regulation of renal potassium excretion and potassium concentration of the body fluids. Thus, aldosterone is even more important as a regulator of potassium concentration than it is for sodium concentration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. АСТН: Incorrect as ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone) has a minor role in aldosterone secretion compared to the renin-angiotensin system or serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Incorrect because hypernatremia would typically suppress aldosterone secretion as the body would seek to excrete excess sodium.

 

Option D. Exogenous steroid: Incorrect as exogenous steroids, depending on their nature, usually suppress endogenous steroid hormone production including aldosterone through feedback mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is a potent stimulator of aldosterone secretion as aldosterone functions primarily to regulate potassium levels in the body, promoting its excretion through the kidneys while enhancing sodium reabsorption, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and blood pressure.

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis

 

Triazoles include drugs like Itraconazole , Voriconazole , Fluconazole and Posaconazole. They are antifungal drugs that act by inhibiting 14-α demethylase , which prevents the conversion of Lanosterol to Ergosterol , thereby inhibiting the fungal cell wall synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis: This mechanism is characteristic of nucleoside analogues such as flucytosine, which are incorporated into RNA and disrupt protein synthesis.

 

Option C. Forms pores in fungal membranes: This mechanism is characteristic of polyenes, such as amphotericin B and nystatin, which bind to ergosterol and form pores in the fungal cell membrane.

 

Option D. Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi: This mechanism is characteristic of allylamines, such as terbinafine and naftifine, which inhibit the enzyme squalene epoxidase, leading to ergosterol depletion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
What are the derivatives of the marked cells? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Odontoblasts

2. Sympathetic chain

3. Melanocytes

4. Nephrogenic cord

5. Bulbus cordis

6. Conotruncal septum
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3, 6

 

Explanation

 

The cells referred to in the question are neural crest cells (NCC), identified adjacent to the neural tube (NT). These cells are significant in developmental biology and are often considered a fourth germ layer due to their extensive differentiation potential across various organs and tissues, exclusive to vertebrates. NCCs transform into various cell types based on their migration path:

 

Dorsal region migration leads to the formation of sensory neurons.

 

Ventral region migration results in the differentiation into sympathetic neurons.

 

These cells are pivotal in developing peripheral nervous system components, craniofacial structures (including bones, cartilage, teeth, and facial muscles), and cardiovascular system components such as the heart.

 

1. Odontoblasts : Correct, as these are the cells responsible for dentin formation in teeth, derived from neural crest cells.

 

2. Sympathetic chain : Correct, neural crest cells form the sympathetic ganglia, part of the autonomic nervous system.

 

3. Melanocytes : Correct, these pigment-producing cells in the skin and hair are derived from neural crest cells.

 

6. Conotruncal septum : Correct, this component of the heart, crucial for the division of the pulmonary artery and aorta, is derived from neural crest cells.

 

In trunk region, NCC form:

 

  • Melanocytes
  • Sensory ganglia
  • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
  • Schwann cells
  • Adrenal medulla cells
  • In the cranial region, they contribute to the:
  • Craniofacial skeleton
  • Neurons for cranial ganglia
  • Satellite glial cells
  • Melanocytes
  • Some of the other neural crest derivatives are
  • C cells of the thyroid gland
  • Conotruncal septum in the heart
  • Odontoblasts
  • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Nephrogenic cord : Incorrect, as it is involved in the development of the kidneys and does not derive from neural crest cells.

 

5. Bulbus cordis : Incorrect, this embryonic heart structure does not originate from neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells (NCCs), stemming from the embryonic ectoderm and unique to vertebrates, play an essential role in forming various tissues and organs like the peripheral nervous system and craniofacial structures during development. These cells migrate and differentiate into diverse cell types based on their location in the body, contributing significantly to the development of sensory and sympathetic neurons, craniofacial elements, and cardiovascular structures.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).

 

The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

The concentration of chloride on the luminal side is more when compared to sodium, glucose, and amino acids.

 

In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes thus decreasing their concentrations markedly along the length of the proximal tubule. Thus, the solution will have a higher concentration of chloride which is around 105 mEg/L.

 

In the second half of the proximal tubule, sodium gets re-absorbed along with chloride. Higher chloride (approx. 140meq/L) concentration favors its own diffusion from the lumen into the renal interstitial fluid.

 

Proximal tubule’s high permeability to water, increases water reabsorption thus helps in maintaining sodium concentration and total osmolarity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Their concentration decreases significantly due to nearly complete reabsorption.

 

Option B. Glucose: Similarly, glucose concentration decreases significantly because of active reabsorption.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: Its concentration also decreases due to active reabsorption facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule does not decrease as significantly as amino acids, glucose, and bicarbonate due to the preferential reabsorption of these other solutes in the early segments of the PCT.

questions.text: Corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Betamethasone

 

Corticosteroids are used in pregnant females delivering premature babies in order to prevent Respiratory Distress Syndrome in the newborn due to inadequate levels of surfactants in the lungs of premature babies. Corticosteroids also reduce the chances of development of Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Intraventricular Hemorrhage in the newborn.

 

For this purpose, we can use either Dexamethasone or Betamethasone.

 

Dose:

 

  1. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly x 4 doses
  2. Betamethasone 12mg 24 hourly x 2 doses

 

Total dose should be 24 mg in 48 hrs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocortisone: Hydrocortisone is not typically used for fetal lung maturation. It is more commonly used for adrenal insufficiency and inflammatory conditions.

 

Option B. Triamcinolone: Triamcinolone is not indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation. It is primarily used for its anti-inflammatory effects in various conditions.

 

Option C. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is also not typically used for this purpose. It is often used for its potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties in various conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Betamethasone is the corticosteroid of choice for stimulating fetal lung maturation in preterm labor, administered to reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome and other complications associated with preterm birth.

questions.text: What is the function of Tubuloglomerular feedback? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Regulate GFR

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

 

The major function of autoregulation in the kidneys is to maintain a relatively constant GFR and to allow precise control of renal excretion of water and solutes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease plasma sodium: Incorrect as the primary function of tubuloglomerular feedback is not to decrease plasma sodium but to adjust renal blood flow and filtration to maintain stable GFR.

 

Option C. Increase plasma volume: Incorrect, tubuloglomerular feedback does not directly function to increase plasma volume; rather, it regulates the filtration rate to maintain balance.

 

Option D. Decrease tubular secretion: Incorrect, this feedback specifically regulates GFR, not tubular secretion processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is an adaptive mechanism in the kidneys that helps regulate GFR in response to changes in blood pressure and filtrate flow rate, ensuring stable renal function and homeostasis.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formication (the sensation of insects crawling under the skin) is a classic tactile hallucination associated with chronic cocaine intoxication, also known as Magnan’s phenomenon or “cocaine bugs.”

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin

 

Explanation

 

All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

 

Gastric Acid Secretion:

 

  • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.

 

Stimulation of ECL Cells:

 

  1. Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  2. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  3. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.

 

Role of Serotonin:

 

  • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text: Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) acts on which of the following Tyrosine Receptor Kinases? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. TRK B

 

Explanation: 

 

Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) specifically binds to and activates TRK B receptors. TRK B (tropomyosin receptor kinase B) is a transmembrane receptor with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity. When BDNF binds to TRK B, it triggers autophosphorylation of the receptor, activating multiple signaling pathways including MAPK, PI3K, and PLCγ pathways. This activation plays crucial roles in neuronal survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity, particularly in long-term potentiation (LTP).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: TRK A serves as the high-affinity receptor for nerve growth factor (NGF), not BDNF. TRK A is primarily expressed in nociceptive neurons and sympathetic ganglia.
  • Option C: TRK C is the primary receptor for neurotrophin-3 (NT-3). It is predominantly expressed in proprioceptive neurons and plays important roles in sensory neuron development.
  • Option D: This is not a recognized member of the Trk receptor family. The mammalian Trk family consists only of TRK A, TRK B, and TRK C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BDNF specifically binds to TRK B receptors, initiating crucial signaling cascades that support neuronal survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity in the central nervous system.

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Axillary nerve

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of injury to axillary nerve which leads to deltoid muscle palsy.

 

The deltoid muscle is supplied by the axillary nerve. Iatrogenic damage to the axillary nerve can happen during transaxillary procedures on the shoulder with lateral deltoid-splitting incisions or while administering IM injections inappropriately. But, note that this nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocation (most commonly anterior type) or fractures of the humeral neck as both the nerve and the posterior circumflex vessels (pass horizontally and posterior to the neck of the humerus).

 

 

Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to:

 

  • Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Retropulsion (extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees) is impossible.
  • Atrophy of the Deltoid muscle leading to the loss of muscle contours of the shoulder
  • Loss of sensation in the Regimental badge area

 

The described symptoms point towards a condition known as "Shoulder Injury Related to Vaccine Administration" (SIRVA). SIRVA can occur if the vaccine is injected too high in the upper arm, potentially causing inflammation or damage to the structures underlying the deltoid muscle, especially the axillary nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotator Cuff: The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) that stabilize and allow various movements of the shoulder joint. Injury to the rotator cuff often results from trauma, repetitive use, or degeneration and leads to pain, especially with overhead activities, and weakness in the arm. A rotator cuff injury would not typically cause the "flabby, flat, asymmetrical" appearance described unless there was a significant tear and muscle atrophy. However, this type of injury wouldn't be directly associated with vaccine administration.

 

Option B. Posterior Circumflex Artery: The posterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery that runs posteriorly around the surgical neck of the humerus. Injury to this artery might result in bleeding and potentially hematoma formation but wouldn't lead to the described flabby, flat appearance of the shoulder or loss of contour.

 

Option C. Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Arm: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, also known as the lateral brachial cutaneous nerve, is a sensory nerve that provides sensation to the lateral part of the upper arm. Injury to this nerve would result in sensory loss or tingling in its distribution area but would not cause the observed morphological changes or affect the contour of the shoulder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. It also carries sensory fibers for the skin over a part of the deltoid (known as the "regimental badge area").

 

Damage to the axillary nerve can result from shoulder dislocations or, as in this case, a vaccine administered too high on the arm. Injury to the axillary nerve would cause paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to a flat shoulder appearance and loss of the normal rounded contour of the deltoid. Over time, if the nerve does not recover, the deltoid muscle may atrophy, further accentuating the flat appearance.

questions.text: What is the site of action of amphotericin B in fungi? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cell membrane

 

Amphotericin B is an antifungal drug that acts by sequestering ergosterol in the cell membrane, it leads to formation of pores in the cell membrane that leads to leakage of cytosolic contents out of the cell and eventually death of the fungus.. It is the drug of choice in systemic fungal infections , mucormycosis , cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleic acid: Amphotericin B does not target nucleic acids. Antifungal drugs that affect nucleic acid synthesis include flucytosine.

 

Option B. Ribosome: Amphotericin B does not target ribosomes. Antifungal drugs that interfere with protein synthesis at the ribosomal level are not commonly used.

 

Option D. Cytoplasm: Amphotericin B acts at the cell membrane, not directly within the cytoplasm. The disruption of the cell membrane causes the loss of cytoplasmic contents.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Mechanism of Action: By binding to ergosterol and forming pores, amphotericin B disrupts the integrity of the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death.
  • Uses: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for treating systemic fungal infections, mucormycosis, and cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amphotericin B targets the cell membrane of fungi by binding to ergosterol, forming pores that lead to leakage of cytoplasmic contents and fungal cell death. It is highly effective in treating severe systemic fungal infections.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is classified as which type of joint? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

 

Explanation:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.

 

Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.

 

Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.

 

Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:

 

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

 

  1. The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  2. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: Which bacterium is typically described as club-shaped? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the causative agent of diphtheria, is typically described as club-shaped. The very name "Corynebacterium" derives from the Greek word "coryne" meaning "club." These bacteria have a characteristic morphology showing swollen ends that give them a club-shaped appearance. They also display a distinctive arrangement described as "Chinese letter" or "cuneiform" formation, where bacterial cells tend to lie at acute angles to each other due to their snapping type of division.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococci - Pneumococci (Streptococcus pneumoniae) are described as "flame-shaped" or "lanceolate" diplococci, not club-shaped. They typically appear as pairs of cocci with pointed ends facing outward, resembling a flame or lance shape. They may be encapsulated and are Gram-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Gonococci - Gonococci (Neisseria gonorrhoeae) are described as "kidney-shaped" or "bean-shaped" diplococci with adjacent sides concave, not club-shaped. They are Gram-negative diplococci that typically appear in pairs with their flat or concave sides facing each other.

 

Option D. V. Cholera - Vibrio cholerae is described as "curved, comma-shaped" Gram-negative bacilli, not club-shaped. These bacteria are curved rods with a single polar flagellum that gives them their characteristic "darting" motility. They do not exhibit the club-shaped morphology seen with Corynebacterium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae displays a distinctive club-shaped morphology with swollen ends and forms characteristic arrangements described as "Chinese letter" or "cuneiform" patterns due to their unique snapping division, which is a key microscopic feature for identification.

choices.text: Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF
Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF
Total ions are more in ICF

questions.text: As a result of the Donnan-Gibbs effect, which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Total ions are more in ICF

 

Explanation:


The Donnan-Gibbs effect describes the unequal distribution of ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion (typically charged proteins) cannot cross the membrane. In cells, the non-diffusible ions are primarily the negatively charged proteins (Prot-) trapped inside. This creates an electrical imbalance that affects the distribution of all permeable ions, ultimately resulting in more total osmotically active particles (ions) inside the cell than outside. This ion imbalance contributes to the osmotic pressure that would make cells swell and potentially rupture if not counterbalanced by the Na, K ATPase pump.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF - This is false. K+ concentration is significantly higher in the intracellular fluid (approximately 140 mEq/L) compared to extracellular fluid (approximately 4.5 mEq/L). The Donnan effect actually contributes to this concentration difference.
  • Option b. Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF - Cl- is higher in ECF than in ICF, it is not the primary consequence of the Donnan-Gibbs effect. The key result is the overall ionic imbalance with more total ions in ICF.
  • Option d. All are true - This cannot be correct since option a is false.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Donnan-Gibbs equilibrium results in an asymmetric distribution of ions across cell membranes with more total ions accumulating in the intracellular compartment due to the presence of non-diffusible, negatively charged proteins.

choices.text: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice
Requires excision as it is potentially malignant
It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Singer's nodule? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd

 

Explanation:

 

Singer's nodules (also called Screamer's nodes) appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cords at the junction of anterior one-third with posterior two-thirds. This specific location is the area of maximum vibration of the cord during phonation, making it subject to maximum trauma. They develop due to vocal abuse or misuse when a person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laser therapy is the treatment of choice: This is incorrect. Early cases of vocal nodules are treated conservatively through voice rest and speech therapy, especially in children. Surgery is only required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. Even when surgery is indicated, it can be performed either with cold instruments or laser - neither being designated as the "treatment of choice."

 

Option B. Requires excision as it is potentially malignant: This is incorrect. Singer's nodules are non-neoplastic, benign lesions that form due to trauma from vocal abuse. They have no malignant potential. They develop through a process of submucosal edema and hemorrhage that undergoes hyalinization and fibrosis.

 

Option C. Most common symptom is pain: This is incorrect. Hoarseness is the most common complaint in patients with vocal nodules. Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation may occur as secondary symptoms, but they are not the primary presenting complaint.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Singer's nodules develop at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of vocal cords due to vocal abuse, primarily causing hoarseness, and are initially managed with conservative treatment including voice rest and speech therapy.
